Greetings, Corazon Aquino: Mother of Asian Democracy. From a plain housewife to the first female President of the Philippines, you have made great strides in your struggle against tryanny. Now, let your people reap the riches of the Philippines and fling open the doors to visitors so they may sample a taste of these Fiesta Islands. The people look to you to guide them, for you have shown them the power that they possess. You have brought peaceful revolution to the Philippines - what will you do now?

Corazon Aquino
President of the Philippines

Corazon Aquino was born in 1933 to Jos√© Cojuangco, a former congressman, and his wife Demetria. Both of her parents came from influential families. She attended university in the United States before returning to the Philippines to study law at Far Eastern University. During her studies, she met Benigno 'Ninoy' S. Aquino, Jr, and they wed. Ninoy was active as a politican - and Corazon secretly helped fund his candidacy by selling off part of her inheritance. He rose up the ranks, eventually becoming the youngest Senator in the country. He became an outspoken critic of President Ferdinand Marcos, and when Marcos declared martial law and abolished the constitution in 1972, Corazon's husband was among the first to be imprisoned. Six years later, their family would leave for exile in the United States. Together Ninoy and Corazon lived a happy life, but in 1983, Ninoy returned to the Philippines and was promptly assassinated on the tarmac of Manila International Airport.

Corazon Aquino returned to the Philippines shortly after; she led Ninoy's funeral procession, in which more than two million people participated. The assassination of her husband flung Corazon into politics as she became an active anti-Marcos figure. After Ferdinand Marcos announced a snap election for early 1986, she received one million signatures urging her to run. Marcos spoke out against her, critiquing her lack of experience and her gender, to which she countered with stinging rebukes of Marcos's corruption. The election on February 7, 1986 was marred by widespread electoral fraud, leading to Marcos being declared the winner. In protest, Corazon held a "People's Victory Rally," which drew an enormous crowd. Just 18 days after the election, Ferdinand Marcos fled the country after several military officers broke with him and offered their support to Aquino's claim to victory in the election.

This People Power Revolution signaled the end of authoritarian rule in the Philippines, earning Corazon the nicknames "Mother of Philippine Democracy" and "The Housewife Who Led a Revolution." She immediately issued a Proclamation to establish a new government, issuing a provisional Freedom Constitution until a more formal document could be ratified. She also promulgated two landmark legal codes and re-organized the Supreme Court to be more independent. She tackled the large amount of foreign debt left by the Marcos regime, reducing the Philippines debt-to-GDP ration by 30 percent, partially by popularizing the Philippines as a tourist destination, marketing the country as the "Fiesta Islands" with a distinct culture and exquisite natural beauty. She also oversaw land and agrarian reform in the country, breaking up large estates in favor of those who worked the fields. She also dealt with several natural disasters during her presidency, including the 1990 Luzon earthquake, the 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, and 1991's Tropical Storm Thelma. Despite her prominence and popularity, Corazon refused to run for a second term, choosing to abide by the term limits of the Constitution even though it was established after her election. She continued to be active in charitable, social, and political endeavors up until her death on August 1, 2009. The Philippines mourned the loss of the Housewife Who Led a Revolution with nation-wide requiem masses and a funeral escort attended by hundreds of thousands of Filipinos.

Corazon Aquino excels at producing gold, especially once she can get national parks up and running in the late game, but keep an eye on her tourism production - that Manila Sound can be quite powerful!

As Corazon Aquino, Plantations and Farms will be the key to your economy. Make sure to place them strategically in order to gain the maximum effect, but also make sure to leave some room for national parks later in the game - they'll be able to net you a hefty influx of cash!
Kumusta - I am Corazon Aquino, President of the Philippines. What brings you here to our island country?
Would you care to visit one of the Fiesta Islands' many splendors?
How delightful - I look foward to visiting your country.
Let us exchange information about our capitals - to work together requires we know where the other one is, no?
Hello again.
I am most grateful for your generosity.
I'm afraid I must turn your gifts away at this time.
Please accept these tokens of my esteem: fresh coconuts, a stylish Barong Tagalog, and samples of some of my favorite Original Pilipino music!
A country must be open if it is to be free - I accept.
Ha! So that you can make yourself at home at Subic Bay? I swear that you shall not enter this country.
The path to peace and democracy is a global one - may we enter your lands in pursuit of that goal?
Of course! We, the Filipinos, thank you for what you do.
Impossible.
Do you consider yourself a friend of freedom - Would you proclaim to be a friend of the Philippines?
Outstanding.
A disappointing decision.
Will you stand with me? The People Power Revolution is not something for only the Philippines; others around the world must know the sweet taste of freedom.
You understand that freedom is essential, and your people relish their liberties.
You crush your people under the weight of your tyranny. Can't you see the harm you are doing?
The sovereignty of the Philippines must be respected. Remove your troops at once.
A fair exchange for both our nations - I accept.
I cannot accept this.
I have dealt with worse - your words do not frighten me.
You crush the spirit of freedom; you seek to break it by indignities and terror. I cannot abide by that (Denounces You).
You may think me but a humble housewife, but I will fight for my country until the very end. I shall not submit.
You have gone too far - the spirit of democracy that inheres in our race and animates my actions can not be allowed to die.
I agree - now is the time for peace.
No, the score is not yet settled.
I come to you to ask for a cessation of hostilities. What do you say?
And so it seems I must lay to rest this restless dream of Philippine freedom.
And so it seems I must lay to rest this restless dream of Philippine freedom.
